meetup-Bucharest-Data-Science-Meetup-235.description:
This session will be an introductory talk on how to use Neo4J ( https://neo4j.com/ ) in its capacity as a graph analytics engine. The target audience is SQL developers.

We'll start with an overview of Neo4J and its query language Cypher before moving on to a few worked examples where we'll build and query the same data set using first relational databases and then Neo4J.

We'll also cover graph modeling, query optimization and show an example of procedures which were introduced in the 3.0 version of Neo4J.

What is Neo4J?

Here's a good summary by Emil Eifrem, creator of Neo4J:
Most applications today handle data that is deeply associative, i.e. structured as graphs (networks). The most obvious example of this is social networking sites, but even tagging systems, content management systems and wikis deal with inherently hierarchical or graph-shaped data.
This turns out to be a problem because it’s difficult to deal with recursive data structures in traditional relational databases. In essence, each traversal along a link in a graph is a join, and joins are known to be very expensive. Furthermore, with user-driven content, it is difficult to pre-conceive the exact schema of the data that will be handled. Unfortunately, the relational model requires upfront schemas and makes it difficult to fit this more dynamic and ad-hoc data.
A graph database uses nodes, relationships between nodes and key-value properties instead of tables to represent information. This model is typically substantially faster for associative data sets and uses a schema-less, bottoms-up model that is ideal for capturing ad-hoc and rapidly changing data.
meetup-Bucharest-Data-Science-Meetup-235.title: Presentation - Beginners - Introduction to Neo4J

meetup-Cluj-WEB-Developers-237632838.description:
Fighting macro-corruption with microservices - theory, back-end, front-end, Docker and Kubernetes 


No longer does one app “rule them all”

From a user experience perspective, architectural styles have evolved to what we now might call "pay by the drink". Where we don’t just offer a single monolithic platform, we offer a multidimensional approach where users can pick and choose the workflows and micro apps of their choice.

A similar trend is also happening in software development, where microservices are now the mainstream approach for scalable systems architecture. Many software engineers are making the transition from monolithic architectures to microservice architectures. This approach has until most recently been limited to back-end services. As development is much more complicated when using microservices as building blocks for a frontend solutions, especially with the latest JS frameworks that promote a monolithic approach to front-end architecture.

We will give an overview of the theory of microservices – what they are and why you would use them. We will then delve into the dark arts of back-end development, explaining how you can construct a winning product with microservices whilst avoiding its pitfalls. We will also discuss methods of rolling your own Frontend app in a world of backend microservices and tackling the challenges of monolithic frontend apps when working with microservices as backend.
  The presentation will cover:

• Background on what microservices are and why you would use them

• A walk through of a backend application development and architecture using microservices to compare and contrast  traditional architectural methodologies

• A discuss on the ways of rolling your own frontend app in a world of backend microservices and ways of tackling challenges of having a monolithic frontend app working with microservices as backend

• Finally, no discussion of microservices would be complete without touching on the integration of Docker and Kubernetes from a developer’s perspective
 

Speakers:

Oliver Butterfield (Platform Lead) is ComplyAdvantage’s primary driving towards adopting a microservice architecture. Oliver previously worked in the server hosting industry and as one of the first team members became the de facto DevOps Engineer in the early days of ComplyAdvantage. Fast forward three years and he's now overseeing development of our client-facing services, including the refactoring of the core application from a monolith to microservices. Oliver is currently excited by distributed computing and performance technologies, such as Kubernetes, AWS, NewRelic and Go.

Persic Alexandru Cristian (Backend Lead) studied computer science at "Stefan cel Mare" University, followed by a masters degree in software engineering (apparently 5 years of study was not good enough). At University he started working at an outsource company using Microsoft technologies and enjoyed each step from helping with JavaScript to implementing custom workflows in SharePoint. After 5 years he saw the light and moved to Python/Django, building a mobile advertising platform from the ground up. In 4 years he managed to gain plenty of experience in managing the implementation, deployment, and maintenance of a large scale web application. In 2016 Cristi made a daring move and joined ComplyAdvantage in the quest of finding once more the excitement of building a new and successful product, all the while fighting crime like any other regular superhero.
  Kun Andrei (FrontEnd Lead) graduated from Technical University of Cluj-Napoca, studying Electronics, Telecommunications and Information Technology. Since then he's been working as a Web Developer on both backend and frontend, though finally focussing on the latter. He followed his passion for UI and the latest frontend technologies. After he gained experience with various corporations and outsourcing companies he was lured by the opportunities of a young and ambitious startup team where he could take ownership of his work and put his own mark on products. Joining ComplyAdvantage was the right step in this direction, he now takes care of the company's front-end apps.
  Andrew Smith (DevOps Lead) studied Mathematics at Warwick University (UK). Graduating in 2012 with no idea what he wanted to do as a career, he fell into a Release Engineering Role at a London FinTech company. Three years later, in January 2016, he joined ComplyAdvantage as their first DevOps Engineer (a far more morally fulfilling role). He has implemented technology, infrastructure, and procedures to effectively and reliably go "From Idea to Production" (to quote GitLab) and to keep everything highly available once it's there. Outside of work, you'll most likely find him at the nearest venue playing loud music, performing culinary experimentation or creating fine works of art in MS Paint.

Schedule: 

18:00 - 18:15 - Arrival time. Come in, get your name tag, have some snacks, pour yourself a cup of coffee/tea and meet us!

18:15 - 19:00 - presentation

19:00 - 19:15 - Let's take a break, enjoy some refreshments and network some more! Food and drink provided.

19:15 - 20:00 - presentation continues

20:00 - 20:15 - Conclusions

___________________________________________ 

Why to attend? 

 To learn as to what others are doing; 

 To ask questions; 

 To network;

 To relax and have a chat;

 To speak about your products and services;

 To build or to retain old connections;

__________________________________________  


Registration here on Meetup is mandatory for this event!

meetup-Cluj-fp-236791113.description:
Programul intalnirii:
6:30 - 7:00 sosirea participantilor + pizza din partea Ullink
7:00 - 8:30 - Denis Rosca - Generic Programming in Scala: Type Class Derivation

Type class derivation is an advanced programming technique that facilitates safe processing of Scala's case classes and sealed traits in generic ways while decreasing code duplication and boilerplate.

Traditionally, generic programs tasked with handling of arbitrary ADTs (e.g. serialization libraries) have made heavy use of runtime reflection APIs while sacrificing safety. Typically those libraries provide default instances for "standard" types and various ways of combining them. Library users must write instances for their own data types in terms of those. 

This is usually a time consuming and laborious process, but it is nevertheless completely mechanical, based entirely on the structure of the types involved. So wouldn't it be nice if we could persuade the Scala compiler to use the structure of those types and do the work for us? Building on [shapeless's](https://github.com/milessabin/shapeless/) core generic programming primitives and support for automatic type class derivation we can!

In this talk we'll see how taking advantage of automatic derivation reduces boilerplate & mechanical code. Along the way we'll discover the surprisingly simple underlying mechanism that allows us to do that.
meetup-Cluj-fp-236791113.title: Generic Programming in Scala: Type Class Derivation

meetup-Internet-of-Things-Timisoara-2373.description:
For the first event of our meetup this year we are bringing in quite interesting presentations with both theoretical and practical stuff from two of the most involved IoT specialists in Timisoara.


Firstly, Radu Motisan will guide us through an engaging hands-on demonstration on modules and  technologies like NodeMCU, Teensy, Onion, LoRAWAN, he is recently involving in his well known uRADMonitor project.

Radu will deliver a quick programming demonstration to show to the audience how all the things mentioned before are orchestrated and will also present the most recent prototype of the uRADMonitor CITY version of his product.


For the second presentation, Catalin Gheorghiu will approach topics related to the usage of SQL database on IoT devices. Starting from the power the IoT devices feature currently, Catalin will demonstrate that it makes total sense to run SQL database engines on these devices.

Involving a real world scenario and real hardware, the presentation will explain how and what for SQL databases work within the field gateway concept, generating expected benefits and making best use of the features  and resources available.

meetup-Product-Camp-Bucharest-Meetup-237.description:
Hi Productcampers,

This month Andrei Romanescu, mentor for go-getters, will talk about "How to Accelerate Your Startup and Turn it Into a Business"

Throughout his 20-years career, Andrei developed a strong passion for People, Operational Excellence and Customer Delight. He likes to see opportunities when everyone else spots challenges, build on strengths, and strategize businesses.

Here is a short summary of his talk:

"Having a full time job and developing your own business in parallel? Possible. 

What does a premium desserts business has in common with IT? Quite a lot. 

Join us and find out how a family turned a hobby that had nothing to do with their day2day jobs into a business with an annual growth rate of 70%-80%. 

Listen to their story about:

(a) how they developed and marketed the products;

(b) how they differentiated the brand and increased sales on a very competitive market driven by price; 

(c) the challenges they had to overcome and mistakes they made as entrepreneurs so you avoid the traps. 

The sweet business we will be talking about: www.cupcakephilosophy.ro; 

www.facebook.com/cupcakephilosophy"

As always in the second part we have Open Space and you are invited to bring your topics about Product Development, Startup Businesses, or anything else related to our topic.

Agenda:

18:45 - 19:00  Welcome Product Campers

19:00 - 19:10  Intro

19:10 - 20:10  "Accelerate your startup. Turn it in2 a business" by Andrei Romanescu

20:10 - 20:20  BREAK

20:20 - 21:15    OPEN SPACE

See you there!

Adrian & Vlad

meetup-Tabara-de-Testare-Timisoara-mktmf.description:
Andreea Popescu a tinut un workshop de usability la Tabara de Toamna si a fost foarte apreciat.

Noi am invitat-o pe Andreea sa tina workshopul si in Timisoara.

===========================================

Mai jos e lista cu propunerile pe urmatorul an:

- Training SQL - Nivel Mediu (recapitulare nivel Basic, la inceput)

- Time and Risk Management

- Comunicare - colegi, dev/tester

* Biblioteca cu informatii utile:

- certificari, carti, linkuri (recomandare: http://testhuddle.com/)

- Technical movie nights: Pluralsight, Coursera

- UFT (QTP), Selenium WebDriver, TFS, SoapUI (basic training)

* Co-interesare: traininguri, conferinte, certificari

- Prezentari si workshop-uri "Eu am mai facut si vreau sa ajut"

- Prezentation Skills (Moderator Surpriza)

- .Net, Java, Html, CSS, Notiuni de OOP, etc - Basic -> Intermediate

- Prezentari cu traineri certificati

- Add fun stuff

- Database performance testing

- implementarea unor design patterns in testarea automata (in afara de Page Objects)

- Cum tot mai multi lucreaza in Agile, poate ar fi interesanta prezentarea unui mediu de continuos integration (principii, cum se lucreaza cu el si ce se poate face) din perspectiva testarii. - Done - la editia aniversara de 3 ani.

meetup-The-Bucharest-Agile-Software-Meet.description:
Hi,

We are ready for a new season of awesome Agile Talks events. Start date is 14th of February.

Arthur Kerpician and  Radu Mazilu have prepared for our community one hour talk, "From zero to (almost) hero - how to build a commercial product in your own time".  They have build scrumvee.com product and they want to share their experience with us: 

We knew from the first hours of eMAG's Mobile Edition Hackathon 2015, that we got ourselves hooked on this project and we won't escape it anytime soon. One year passed, dozens of weekends and evenings burned coding and here we are: providing all fellow developers a Scrum tool that would make the Agile experience trackable, accurate and more fun. And it's free for all!

During the one hour meet-up, we'll walk you through the core concepts used in our product, how it evolved from spaghetti to a fancy looking dinner, technologies of choice, milestones and future developments waiting to be tackled. A demo involving you, our end-user, will showcase all the features and advantages of our product. Whoever survives the demo, will be granted access to our pizza and beer cave ;)


After 11 years of entrepreneurship, Arthur joined the eMAG team, where he performed as a software developer and a team manager. Arthur's working now for two start-ups, co-owning one of them and doing the most enjoyable things: trying and catching.

After working on personal projects and doing freelance gigs for over 6 years, Radu is now working during the day as a software developer at eMAG and as an Android developer at night. He's really annoyed by waiting ridiculous amounts of time for a page to load, so he's also known as "The Query Slayer".


Agenda:

18:45 - 19:00 Arriving, socializing
19:00 - 19:10 Introduction
19:10 - 20:00 TBD 
20:00 - 20:15 Break
20:15- 21:00 Open Space - ask the speakers for more details or propose interesting topics
21:00 - 21:10 Closing

See you on 14th February!

meetup-UX-Casual-Tuesday-236664822.description:
Hi guys,

For this session, we plan on having a relaxed talk about what user experience is. We'll cover basic topics such as research, workflows, wireframe, free tools to make your day better and much more. 


I encourage everyone to attend and share tips & tricks with our new members which just hopped on the UX train. 

Agenda 

18:45 - 19:00 — Time to meet up, networking;

19:00 - 19:15 — Intro — Ice breaker exercise 

19:15 - 20:15 — A beginners guide

20:15 - 20:30 — Wrap-up and more networking;

20:30 - TBD — Maybe grab a beer at Jax!

See you soon,

Paul
meetup-UX-Casual-Tuesday-236664822.title: #003 | A beginners guide

meetup-angularjs-cluj-zhpzmmywdbcc.description:
Starting today we are planning on holding a recurring meetup in which we will discuss, document, build and more importantly contribute to open source projects.

We have used open source projects in our every day job, but rarely had the chance to contribute back and understand the environment better.

This meetup will help you improve your developer skills, working in a team, understanding how open source works and how to architect, develop and maintain an open source project.

The event will last for 2 hours in which we will do the following:

1. Discuss code you already worked on that you are thinking of making open source

2. Discuss ideas of open source projects you would like to contribute to

3. Organise your project: code, architecture, comments, issues, PRs, community message.

4. Contribute by writing code to one or multiple github repositories.

At the end of each event we will take a look at what PRs have been added/merged, see how we can improve our code and share new ideas with the community.

Requirements:

• laptop


• 2 hours of your time


• fun learning attitude


Registration fee is $2 as always, to make sure everyone who registers also attends, from which we buy snacks/drinks for the event :).
meetup-angularjs-cluj-zhpzmmywdbcc.title: Workshop: Open Source your Code

meetup-aws-ro-237241801.description:
Hi Everyone,

We have our presenter for Feb 23rd.

Marius Mitrofan has once been tasked with developing a fully functional MyBB forum that was of course expected to be highly-scalable, highly-available and as secure as possible. So he chose to use AWS CloudFormation and then he wrote a tutorial on how he did - https://netbears.ro/devops/launch-mybb-cloudformation-stack-aws/.

For our next meeting Marius will present it as a practical use case for AWS CloudFormation and VPC.

See you next time!

Ciprian
meetup-aws-ro-237241801.title: Launch a MyBB stack using AWS CloudFormation

meetup-eat-pray-tech-237058138.description:
Tema zilei: Viața și injustițiile ei


Suntem înconjurați de tehnologie, ne hrănim cu ea și, în consecință, ne influențează modul în care gândim și trăim. 

La eat/pray/tech dorim să ne întâlnim și să ne împingem gândurile dincolo de limitările acesteia. Vrem să căutăm răspunsuri acolo unde 1+1 nu dă întotdeauna 2.

Ne frământăm cu întrebările importante și dificile ale vieții, îndreptându-ne ochii, inima și mintea spre Dumnezeu.

Nu în ultimul rând, ne întâlnim ca să ne cunoaștem mai bine, să luăm micul dejun împreună și, bineînțeles, și prima doză de cafeină a zilei.

Unde?

HUGO Restaurants, cladirea The Office, Bulevardul 21 Decembrie 1989 nr. 77.

Cost

Taxa este de 20 RON și se va achita la locație, numerar. Aceasta reprezintă contravaloarea unui bogat mic dejun, cu suc și cafea.


Social Media

O să comunicăm pe Facebook, Twitter si Instagram folosind #EatPrayTech.
meetup-eat-pray-tech-237058138.title: eat/pray/tech #9

meetup-fullstack-cluj-zhpzmmywpblc.description:
Starting today we are planning on holding a recurring meetup in which we will discuss, document, build and more importantly contribute to open source projects.

We have used open source projects in our every day job, but rarely had the chance to contribute back and understand the environment better.

This meetup will help you improve your developer skills, working in a team, understanding how open source works and how to architect, develop and maintain an open source project.

The event will be last for 2 hours in which we will do the following:

1. Discuss code you already worked on that you are thinking of making open source

2. Discuss ideas of open source projects you would like to contribute to

3. Organise your project: code, architecture, comments, issues, PRs, community message.

4. Contribute by writing code to one or multiple github repositories.

At the end of each event we will take a look at what PRs have been added/merged, see how we can improve our code and share new ideas with the community.

Requirements:

• laptop


• 2 hours of your time


• fun learning attitude


Registration fee is $2 as always, to make sure everyone who registers also attends, from which we buy snacks/drinks for the event :).

meetup-the-javascript-timisoara-group-23.description:
How do you "type" JavaScript?

In the context of having various JavaScript flavors & languages that compile to JS, that offer static typing, the aim of this meetup is to answer a few questions?


• will static types make us write better code?
• will static types reduce the number of bugs?
• are dynamic languages suited for "small" projects only?
• can I mix static & dynamic types?
• should I switch to a statically typed JavaScript flavor?

To help us answer these questions, we have invited 2 special guests:

• Radu Marinescu
• Radu Fericean


Moderator: Andrei Pfeiffer

This meetup will take place in a panel-like format, no presentations. The audience is welcome to contribute to the discussion.

<Have a subject you want to talk about? Contact us. We're always eager to hear from you!>
meetup-the-javascript-timisoara-group-23.title: tim.js meetup 36: How do you "type" JavaScript?
